required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Concomitant Use of Azacitidine and Homoharringtonine in Children With Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia

lead_sponsor.agency: Air Force Military Medical University, China

collaborator.agency: The Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University
The Second Hospital of Hebei Medical University

clinical_study.source: Air Force Military Medical University, China

brief_summary.textblock: Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) has a poor prognosis in general, with hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) remaining the standard of care for cure. Azacitidine and homoharringtonine, which exhibited a anticancer mechanism and has been widely used in patients with relapse/refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, the efficacy of these agents has not been elucidated in children with JMML. The primary objective is to assess the treatment effect on response rate in this subject population.

primary_outcome.measure: Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) response rate at end of 4 Months
primary_outcome.description: Defined as proportion of patients with sustained clinical complete remission [cCR] or clinical partial remission [cPR] according to the International JMML response criteria in Niemeyer 2014 at 3 months (28 days cycles). Response must be sustained for at least 4 weeks either in the 4-week period preceding or succeeding 3 months (ie, sustained over the period minimum 2 months to end of 3 months, or end of 3 months to end of 4 months).

intervention.description: Concommitant use of azacitidine and homoharringtonine

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newly diagnosed JMML, with PB and BM confirming diagnosis prior to informed consent signature, with one of the following:
1. somatic mutation in PTPN11
2. somatic mutation in KRAS
3. somatic mutation in NRAS and HbF % > 5x normal value for age
4. clinical diagnosis of neurofibromatosis Type 1.
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1. Any condition that would prevent the subject from participating in the study.
2. Any condition including the presence of laboratory abnormalities, which places the subject at unacceptable risk if participated in the study.
3. Any condition that confounds the ability to interpret data from the study.

facility.name: Institute of Hematology & Blood Diseases Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Air Force Military Medical University, China
